trans-unit.source: Testing the performance of a cloud service | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Testing the performance of a cloud service | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Test the performance of a cloud service using the Visual Studio profiler
trans-unit.target: Test the performance of a cloud service using the Visual Studio profiler

trans-unit.source: Testing the performance of a cloud service
trans-unit.target: Testing the performance of a cloud service

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: You can test the performance of a cloud service in the following ways:
trans-unit.target: You can test the performance of a cloud service in the following ways:

trans-unit.source: Use Azure Diagnostics to collect information about requests and connections, and to review site statistics that show how the service performs from a customer perspective.
trans-unit.target: Use Azure Diagnostics to collect information about requests and connections, and to review site statistics that show how the service performs from a customer perspective.

trans-unit.source: To get started with , see <link><linkText>Configuring diagnostics for Azure Cloud Services and Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To get started with , see <link><linkText>Configuring diagnostics for Azure Cloud Services and Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Use the Visual Studio profiler to get an in-depth analysis of the computational aspects of how the service runs.
trans-unit.target: Use the Visual Studio profiler to get an in-depth analysis of the computational aspects of how the service runs.

trans-unit.source: As this topic describes, you can use the profiler to measure performance as a service runs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: As this topic describes, you can use the profiler to measure performance as a service runs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to use the profiler to measure performance as a service runs locally in a compute emulator, see <link><linkText>Testing the Performance of an Azure Cloud Service Locally in the Compute Emulator Using the Visual Studio Profiler</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to use the profiler to measure performance as a service runs locally in a compute emulator, see <link><linkText>Testing the Performance of an Azure Cloud Service Locally in the Compute Emulator Using the Visual Studio Profiler</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Choosing a performance testing method
trans-unit.target: Choosing a performance testing method

trans-unit.source: Use Azure Diagnostics to collect:
trans-unit.target: Use Azure Diagnostics to collect:

trans-unit.source: Statistics on web pages or services, such as requests and connections.
trans-unit.target: Statistics on web pages or services, such as requests and connections.

trans-unit.source: Statistics on roles, such as how often a role is restarted.
trans-unit.target: Statistics on roles, such as how often a role is restarted.

trans-unit.source: Overall information about memory usage, such as the percentage of time that the garbage collector takes or the memory set of a running role.
trans-unit.target: Overall information about memory usage, such as the percentage of time that the garbage collector takes or the memory set of a running role.

trans-unit.source: Use the Visual Studio profiler to:
trans-unit.target: Use the Visual Studio profiler to:

trans-unit.source: Determine which functions take the most time.
trans-unit.target: Determine which functions take the most time.

trans-unit.source: Measure how much time each part of a computationally intensive program takes.
trans-unit.target: Measure how much time each part of a computationally intensive program takes.

trans-unit.source: Compare detailed performance reports for two versions of a service.
trans-unit.target: Compare detailed performance reports for two versions of a service.

trans-unit.source: Analyze memory allocation in more detail than the level of individual memory allocations.
trans-unit.target: Analyze memory allocation in more detail than the level of individual memory allocations.

trans-unit.source: Analyze concurrency problems in multithreaded code.
trans-unit.target: Analyze concurrency problems in multithreaded code.

trans-unit.source: When you use the profiler, you can collect data when a cloud service runs locally or in Azure.
trans-unit.target: When you use the profiler, you can collect data when a cloud service runs locally or in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Collect profiling data locally to:
trans-unit.target: Collect profiling data locally to:

trans-unit.source: Test the performance of a part of a cloud service, such as the execution of specific worker role, that doesn’t require a realistic simulated load.
trans-unit.target: Test the performance of a part of a cloud service, such as the execution of specific worker role, that doesn’t require a realistic simulated load.

trans-unit.source: Test the performance of a cloud service in isolation, under controlled conditions.
trans-unit.target: Test the performance of a cloud service in isolation, under controlled conditions.

trans-unit.source: Test the performance of a cloud service before you deploy it to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Test the performance of a cloud service before you deploy it to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Test the performance of a cloud service privately, without disturbing the existing deployments.
trans-unit.target: Test the performance of a cloud service privately, without disturbing the existing deployments.

trans-unit.source: Test the performance of the service without incurring charges for running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Test the performance of the service without incurring charges for running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Collect profiling data in Azure to:
trans-unit.target: Collect profiling data in Azure to:

trans-unit.source: Test the performance of a cloud service under a simulated or real load.
trans-unit.target: Test the performance of a cloud service under a simulated or real load.

trans-unit.source: Use the instrumentation method of collecting profiling data, as this topic describes later.
trans-unit.target: Use the instrumentation method of collecting profiling data, as this topic describes later.

trans-unit.source: Test the performance of the service in the same environment as when the service runs in production.
trans-unit.target: Test the performance of the service in the same environment as when the service runs in production.

trans-unit.source: You typically simulate a load to test cloud services under normal or stress conditions.
trans-unit.target: You typically simulate a load to test cloud services under normal or stress conditions.

trans-unit.source: Profiling a cloud service in Azure
trans-unit.target: Profiling a cloud service in Azure

trans-unit.source: When you publish your cloud service from Visual Studio, you can profile the service and specify the profiling settings that give you the information that you want.
trans-unit.target: When you publish your cloud service from Visual Studio, you can profile the service and specify the profiling settings that give you the information that you want.

trans-unit.source: A profiling session is started for each instance of a role.
trans-unit.target: A profiling session is started for each instance of a role.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to publish your service from Visual Studio, see <link><linkText>Publishing to an Azure Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to publish your service from Visual Studio, see <link><linkText>Publishing to an Azure Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To understand more about performance profiling in Visual Studio, see <link><linkText>Beginners Guide to Performance Profiling</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Analyzing Application Performance by Using Profiling Tools</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To understand more about performance profiling in Visual Studio, see <link><linkText>Beginners Guide to Performance Profiling</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Analyzing Application Performance by Using Profiling Tools</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can enable either IntelliTrace or profiling when you publish your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: You can enable either IntelliTrace or profiling when you publish your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: You can't enable both.
trans-unit.target: You can't enable both.

trans-unit.source: Profiler collection methods
trans-unit.target: Profiler collection methods

trans-unit.source: You can use different collection methods for profiling, based on your performance issues:
trans-unit.target: You can use different collection methods for profiling, based on your performance issues:

trans-unit.source: CPU sampling - This method collects application statistics that are useful for initial analysis of CPU utilization issues.
trans-unit.target: CPU sampling - This method collects application statistics that are useful for initial analysis of CPU utilization issues.

trans-unit.source: CPU sampling is the suggested method for starting most performance investigations.
trans-unit.target: CPU sampling is the suggested method for starting most performance investigations.

trans-unit.source: There is a low impact on the application that you are profiling when you collect CPU sampling data.
trans-unit.target: There is a low impact on the application that you are profiling when you collect CPU sampling data.

trans-unit.source: Instrumentation -This method collects detailed timing data that is useful for focused analysis and for analyzing input/output performance issues.
trans-unit.target: Instrumentation -This method collects detailed timing data that is useful for focused analysis and for analyzing input/output performance issues.

trans-unit.source: The instrumentation method records each entry, exit, and function call of the functions in a module during a profiling run.
trans-unit.target: The instrumentation method records each entry, exit, and function call of the functions in a module during a profiling run.

trans-unit.source: This method is useful for gathering detailed timing information about a section of your code and for understanding the impact of input and output operations on application performance.
trans-unit.target: This method is useful for gathering detailed timing information about a section of your code and for understanding the impact of input and output operations on application performance.

trans-unit.source: This method is disabled for a computer running a 32-bit operating system.
trans-unit.target: This method is disabled for a computer running a 32-bit operating system.

trans-unit.source: This option is available only when you run the cloud service in Azure, not locally in the compute emulator.
trans-unit.target: This option is available only when you run the cloud service in Azure, not locally in the compute emulator.

trans-unit.source: .NET Memory Allocation - This method collects .NET Framework memory allocation data by using the sampling profiling method.
trans-unit.target: .NET Memory Allocation - This method collects .NET Framework memory allocation data by using the sampling profiling method.

trans-unit.source: The collected data includes the number and size of allocated objects.
trans-unit.target: The collected data includes the number and size of allocated objects.

trans-unit.source: Concurrency - This method collects resource contention data, and process and thread execution data that is useful in analyzing multi-threaded and multi-process applications.
trans-unit.target: Concurrency - This method collects resource contention data, and process and thread execution data that is useful in analyzing multi-threaded and multi-process applications.

trans-unit.source: The concurrency method collects data for each event that blocks execution of your code, such as when a thread waits for locked access to an application resource to be freed.
trans-unit.target: The concurrency method collects data for each event that blocks execution of your code, such as when a thread waits for locked access to an application resource to be freed.

trans-unit.source: This method is useful for analyzing multi-threaded applications.
trans-unit.target: This method is useful for analyzing multi-threaded applications.

trans-unit.source: You can also enable Tier Interaction Profiling, which provides additional information about the execution times of synchronous ADO.NET calls in functions of multi-tiered applications that communicate with one or more databases.
trans-unit.target: You can also enable Tier Interaction Profiling, which provides additional information about the execution times of synchronous ADO.NET calls in functions of multi-tiered applications that communicate with one or more databases.

trans-unit.source: You can collect tier interaction data with any of the profiling methods.
trans-unit.target: You can collect tier interaction data with any of the profiling methods.

trans-unit.source: For more information about tier interaction profiling, see <link><linkText>Tier Interactions View</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about tier interaction profiling, see <link><linkText>Tier Interactions View</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Configuring profiling settings
trans-unit.target: Configuring profiling settings

trans-unit.source: The following illustration shows how to configure your profiling settings from the Publish Azure Application dialog box.
trans-unit.target: The following illustration shows how to configure your profiling settings from the Publish Azure Application dialog box.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure Profiling Settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure Profiling Settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To enable the Enable profiling check box, you must have the profiler installed on the local computer that you are using to publish your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: To enable the Enable profiling check box, you must have the profiler installed on the local computer that you are using to publish your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: By default, the profiler is installed when you install Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: By default, the profiler is installed when you install Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: To configure profiling settings
trans-unit.target: To configure profiling settings

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for your Azure project, and then choose Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for your Azure project, and then choose Publish.

trans-unit.source: For detailed steps about how to publish a cloud service, see <link><linkText>Publishing a cloud service using the Azure tools</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed steps about how to publish a cloud service, see <link><linkText>Publishing a cloud service using the Azure tools</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In the Publish Azure Application dialog box, chose the Advanced Settings tab.
trans-unit.target: In the Publish Azure Application dialog box, chose the Advanced Settings tab.

trans-unit.source: To enable profiling, select the Enable profiling check box.
trans-unit.target: To enable profiling, select the Enable profiling check box.

trans-unit.source: To configure your profiling settings, choose the Settings hyperlink.
trans-unit.target: To configure your profiling settings, choose the Settings hyperlink.

trans-unit.source: The Profiling Settings dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The Profiling Settings dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: From the What method of profiling would you like to use option buttons, choose the type of profiling that you need.
trans-unit.target: From the What method of profiling would you like to use option buttons, choose the type of profiling that you need.

trans-unit.source: To collect the tier interaction profiling data, select the Enable Tier Interaction Profiling check box.
trans-unit.target: To collect the tier interaction profiling data, select the Enable Tier Interaction Profiling check box.

trans-unit.source: To save the settings, choose the OK button.
trans-unit.target: To save the settings, choose the OK button.

trans-unit.source: When you publish this application, these settings are used to create the profiling session for each role.
trans-unit.target: When you publish this application, these settings are used to create the profiling session for each role.

trans-unit.source: Viewing Profiling Reports
trans-unit.target: Viewing Profiling Reports

trans-unit.source: A profiling session is created for each instance of a role in your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: A profiling session is created for each instance of a role in your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: To view your profiling reports of each session from Visual Studio, you can view the Server Explorer window and then choose the Azure Compute node to select an instance of a role.
trans-unit.target: To view your profiling reports of each session from Visual Studio, you can view the Server Explorer window and then choose the Azure Compute node to select an instance of a role.

trans-unit.source: You can then view the profiling report as shown in the following illustration.
trans-unit.target: You can then view the profiling report as shown in the following illustration.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>View Profiling Report from Azure</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>View Profiling Report from Azure</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To view profiling reports
trans-unit.target: To view profiling reports

trans-unit.source: To view the Server Explorer window in Visual Studio, on the menu bar choose View, Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: To view the Server Explorer window in Visual Studio, on the menu bar choose View, Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Choose the Azure Compute node, and then choose the Azure deployment node for the cloud service that you selected to profile when you published from Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Choose the Azure Compute node, and then choose the Azure deployment node for the cloud service that you selected to profile when you published from Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: To view profiling reports for an instance, choose the role in the service, open the shortcut menu for a specific instance, and then choose View Profiling Report.
trans-unit.target: To view profiling reports for an instance, choose the role in the service, open the shortcut menu for a specific instance, and then choose View Profiling Report.

trans-unit.source: The report, a .vsp file, is now downloaded from Azure, and the status of the download appears in the Azure Activity Log. When the download completes, the profiling report appears in a tab in the editor for Visual Studio named <html></html>_<html></html>_<html></html>.vsp. Summary data for the report appears.
trans-unit.target: The report, a .vsp file, is now downloaded from Azure, and the status of the download appears in the Azure Activity Log. When the download completes, the profiling report appears in a tab in the editor for Visual Studio named <html></html>_<html></html>_<html></html>.vsp. Summary data for the report appears.

trans-unit.source: To display different views of the report, in the Current View list, choose the type of view that you want.
trans-unit.target: To display different views of the report, in the Current View list, choose the type of view that you want.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Profiling Tools Report Views</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Profiling Tools Report Views</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Debugging Cloud Services</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Debugging Cloud Services</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Publishing to an Azure Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Publishing to an Azure Cloud Service from Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>
